I.  THE ENSUING PROGRAM 
 
1.  The proposed Financial Sector and Fiscal Management Improvement Program aims to 
support the Government of Tajikistan with reforms to create a more stable financial system, 
enhance access to financial services, and improve fiscal management to accelerate sustainable 
private sector growth. The program will (i) enhance banking sector stability, (ii) improve the 
enabling environment for the financial sector, and (iii) strengthen public financial management. 
The proposed program will support the government’s reform agenda for the financial sector 
outlined in the national development strategy up to 2030 and is consistent with the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  country  partnership  strategy  for  Tajikistan,  2016–2020. 1  The 
programmatic approach policy based loan will finance two subprograms to be implemented during 
2019–2021, with a total amount of $100 million to be financed from Asian Development Fund 
grant resources. The program and the transaction technical assistance (TA) are included in the 
country operations business plan for Tajikistan, 2020–2022.2 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The Government of Tajikistan requested TA to support ongoing financial and public 
management reforms, which are linked to selected reform areas under the ensuing Financial 
Sector and Fiscal Management Improvement Program. The consultation mission discussed the 
results framework, implementation arrangements, cost estimate, and the scope of the TA with the 
government. 
 
3.  The TA will (i) help design and implement reforms and detailed policy actions under the 
ensuing program and (ii) provide policy advice to the government to support fiscal management 
reforms and the development of the financial sector. The TA will also strengthen the capacity of 
the executing and implementing agencies to effectively and sustainably implement the program 
and improve governance. The TA grant of $750,000 will support program preparation and 
implementation of the proposed reform areas for subprograms 1 and 2. Detailed descriptions of 
the outputs and activities are in section B. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
4.  Output 1: Financial stability improved. This output will establish a standby credit line 
for the Individuals Deposit Insurance Fund (IDIF) with the Ministry of Finance (MOF) for initial re-
capitalization of the fund following the liquidation of two large state-owned banks and payouts to 
eligible depositors. The fund may also access financing through the standby credit line in the 
event of future bank failures. IDIF will expand the number of participating banks and the coverage 
level of the deposit insurance system and explore differential deposit insurance coverage for 
women-headed households. This output will develop the IDIF operational framework, improve 
IDIF investment policy, review  arrangements for bank liquidation in relation to IDIF (including 
proceeds received from liquidation), and provide training to IDIF staff to complement all activities. 
This  output  will  also  develop  macroprudential  policy  tools  and  strengthen  the  institutional 
framework for the National Bank of Tajikistan (NBT) Financial Stability Department, including bank 
                                                
1  Government of Tajikistan. 2016. National Development Strategy of the Republic of Tajikistan for the Period up to 
2030. Dushanbe; and ADB. 2016. Country Partnership Strategy: Tajikistan, 2016–2020. Manila. 
2   ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Tajikistan 2020–2022. Manila.

2 
capital requirements and capital buffers, and provide training to NBT staff. This output will also 
improve reporting from commercial banks to NBT on lending to state-owned enterprises. 
 
5.  Output 2: Financial sector strategy developed. This output will prepare a financial 
sector strategy and road map, including steps to rehabilitate the banking industry and enable 
greater competition. The strategy will include targets and actions to improve women’s access to 
financial services and financial inclusion. The previous financial sector strategy covered the period 
2010–2015 and is now outdated. This output will also help increase public awareness of the IDIF 
and reforms under the program, including gender targeted communication and awareness. 
 
6.  Output 3: Government securities market strengthened. This output will help the MOF 
further develop the government securities market, including issuing government securities by 
auction at market pricing, and provide training to MOF staff. 
 
7.  Output 4: Legal and regulatory framework and tax laws for financial sector reviewed 
and revised. This output will review the current insurance supervision and Islamic finance laws 
and regulations to identify areas that need to be enhanced and gaps to be addressed. This review 
will help improve NBT’s regulatory role and develop the market, and will provide training and 
advice to staff of the NBT Insurance Supervision Department.3 This output will also review priority 
tax  reforms  which  are  necessary  to  help  develop  the  financial  sector  and  incorporate 
recommendations into the ongoing tax code review. 
 
8.  Output 5: Public expenditure management improved. This output will help prepare a 
medium-term  budget  framework,  incorporating  capital  expenditure  and  improving  budget 
preparation and dissemination. The medium-term budget framework will also incorporate results 
of  the  gender  analysis  of  the  budget  and  government  expenditure  programs  and  gender 
responsive  budgeting.  This  output  will  also  help  the  MOF  adopt  international  cash-based 
accounting standards, improve financial reporting from state-owned enterprises to the MOF and 
MOF monitoring of fiscal risks, and provide training and capacity building for MOF staff. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $850,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 1.  
 
10.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation and supplies, secretarial assistance, local transport, logistical support, and other 
in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB 
to finance the ensuing program. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  The implementation arrangements for the TA will be aligned with those of the ensuing 
program. ADB’s Public Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division of the Central and 
West Asia Department will administer the TA and select, supervise, and evaluate consultants and 
procure goods (if necessary). The MOF will be the executing agency. The NBT, MOF, IDIF, and

Islamic finance regulatory framework: ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance for Islamic Finance for Inclusive Growth. 
Manila.

the Tax Committee will be the implementing agencies. Senior officers from the MOF and NBT will 
monitor the TA components. The TA will be implemented from December 2019 to December 2021 
(Table 1).

13.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.4 The TA will require a total of 38 person-months of consultancy services 
intermittently (Table 2). ADB will engage international and national consultants individually or as 
a firm using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a standard quality–cost ratio of 
90:10 and will prefer output-based, lump-sum consulting contracts. All disbursements under the 
TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time).
